definition: lit. to use a sacred tripod as cooking pot and jade as ordinary stone (idiom); fig. a waste of precious material/casting pearls before swine
ancient cooking cauldron with two looped handles and three or four legs/pot (dialect)/to enter upon a period of (classical)/Kangxi radical 206/one of the 64 hexagrams of the Book of Changes
frying pan/griddle
clank/clang/sound of metal
jade
dry measure for grain equal to ten dou 斗/ten pecks/one hundred liters
surname Shi
rock/stone/stone inscription/one of the eight categories of ancient musical instruments 八音[ba1 yin1]
extravagant lifestyle
person narrow-minded and shortsighted
with money, you can do anything (idiom)/money talks
to be penniless
one word worth a thousand in gold (idiom); valuable advice/words of enormous weight
clay ox, wooden horse (idiom); shape without substance/worthless object
cow's piss, horse's ulcer (idiom); worthless nonsense/insignificant
lit. the heart of a sheep in the skin of a tiger (idiom)/fig. impressive in appearance but lacking in substance/braggart
Sima Xiangru is meticulous and Mei Gao is fast (idiom)/to each his good points
to cast pearls before swine (idiom)/not to get proper recognition for one's talents
cow and famous steed at the same trough (idiom); fig. the common and the great are treated alike
to buy a wooden box and return the pearls inside/to show poor judgment (idiom)
lit. the old man lost his horse, but it all turned out for the best (idiom)/fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
to beg while playing the xiao 箫 (mouth organ)/cf Wu Zixu 伍子胥, destitute refugee from Chu 楚, busked in Wu town c. 520 BC, then became a powerful politician
lit. almanac from years back (idiom)/obsolete practice/old-fashioned principle
lit. to live on dry provisions and wild herbs (idiom)/fig. to live in abject poverty
